Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ramira

texts.en:
Ramira J. hails from Salimpuno, Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental. She is married with two children. Her husband is a motorcycle driver in their town. At the same time, they also earn a living for the family by growing corn. Ramira is now on her eighth loan cycle, requesting a 10,000 loan for the purchase of fertilizers. She also wishes to set aside a portion of it for labor, especially during harvest.

Her future plans is to till her own land and to be able to send their children to school so that they can attain good jobs in the future.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers for corn crops

loans.name: Ma. Benjie

texts.en:
Mrs. Ma. Benjie O. became a member of Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative on December 11, 2007. She is 33 years of age, married, and blessed with two children who are of school age.

She is engaged in bibingka-making (a traditional layered pudding) as her other source of income. She obtained her previous loan in the amount of PHP 7,000 and has good standing in terms of her scheduled payments.

Now, she's obtaining another loan from the Coop as her 4th cycle in the amount of PHP 9,000 to purchase farm inputs. She said that the profits she earns from her project have been a great help to her family because they can now support their daily needs and the fees of their children who are studying.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs

loans.name: Consepcion

texts.en:
Consepcion M. is from the village of El Paraiso. She is 52 years old. Consepcion is married and has two school-aged children and two who are now grown. To make a living, Consepcion owns and operates a business venture in the food sector, making and selling food. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Consepcion has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2005, Consepcion joined PMPC to gain access to financial services. She wanted to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Consepcion has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business.

Consepcion is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Consepcion from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make prepared food items for sale

loans.name: Anelyn

texts.en:
Mrs. Anelyn S. M., 31 years old, is a resident of Labo, Ozamiz City. She is married and blessed with two children, both of whom are still minor dependents. Her husband is a heavy equipment operator and a cocoland laborer (harvester). Because of the economic crisis they have encountered, she decided to engage in business herself. She registered herself as a dealer of JTY Products, a direct selling company with main products of ready-to-wear clothes, home decor items, and home accessories. She has skills for this kind of business because she has had experience in direct selling since the age of 16. Her business is stable.

As a new member of PAGLAUM MPC, she is applying to us for a loan in the amount of P20,000.00 under the regular loan program to add to her capital from her direct selling business, and the remaining amount will be used for full payment of a lot they acquired.

Her future plan is to provide a better future for her family through her continuing support. She believes that this dream in life will have fulfillment someday through the help of PMPC and Kiva.

loans.use: Additional capital for her direct selling business as well as for full payment of a newly acquired lot

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Mrs. Marilou A. has been a member of Paglaum under the PDP-LP program since April of 2007. She lives in Nilabo, Rizal Zamboanga del Norte, and is married to Daniel A., who is a farmer. They are blessed with two children.

She has requested a loan in the amount of 3,500 for the purpose of obtaining additional capital for her business, which is a "sari-sari" or general store. Her plan for her business is to expand it into a big grocery store someday. Her dream for her family is that all of her children will finish their studies through college so that they can find decent and stable jobs someday.

loans.use: To gain additional capital to buy canned goods for sale

loans.name: Lina

texts.en: A determined and very industrious mother is Mrs. Lina B. L.. She is 45 years old and a widow with seven children who still live with her as her dependents. To support her big family, she engaged herself in making suman from cassava, which is locally known as “Bodbod”, in her house at Calabayan, Ozamiz City. She is also engaged in another type of business, which is vegetable vending. She started this business a long time ago with an initial capital of P2,000.00. Despite her situation, still God is so good. She receives monthly support from her congregation, Happy Church, for her children’s education. As a new member of PAGLAUM MPC, she is applying for a loan amount of P5,000.00 to add to her capital for making “Suman”, a rice delicacy in our country, and for her vegetable vending business. For her future plans, she wants her business to prosper and to be known not only in her local barangay but also in other places.

loans.use: Additional capital for "Suman" and vegetable vending

location.town: Calabayan, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental, Mindan

loans.name: Rogelio

texts.en:
Rogelio S. is a 53-year old chicken grower and a father of three children. He started his poultry business in 1997. His business is doing very well today. He needs additional capital to increase his livelihood. "Before, I was working in the factory as a salesman. My income was not able to suffice all my family expenses that is why I decided to stop working and started a business to manage," he said.

He is asking for a loan of Php 10,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. (CEVI), a micro-finance partner of Kiva in the Philippines. He will use the loan to purchase chicken feed. "With my loan, I have better chance to expand my business all the more." 

Because CEVI has helped him sustain his business for a long time, he remains loyal to CEVI and continues using its services. CEVI provides their clients with not just loans, but also training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To purchase feed

loans.name: Flery

texts.en:
Flery V. is from Antipolo, the capital city of the Rizal Province in the Philippines. She is married to Elisse V., who is 59 and her partner in her business. Flery is the mother of two sons and two daughters. The eldest child, Samuel, is a 31-year old high-school graduate, while the youngest, Flerry Fe, is 20 and a college graduate.

In the year 2000, Flery joined ASHI (Ahon Sa hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines. Since then, she has had access to capital for her business. They utilized their loans as capital for the selling of balot (boiled chicken eggs that have incubated for 18 days) in the city. Local folks are fond of buying balot during evening time while relaxing or during recreation. Since the demand for balot is consistent, the business is successful.

Now on her 13th loan, she is requesting 30,000 pesos as additional capital for the selling of balot and the remaining amount will be used to pay for a videoke machine (a machine used for recreation in which you sing on a television screen with sound, somewhat like Magic Sing) as her secondary business. This machine will be rented out to interested individuals. Singing videoke is one of the most common relaxation strategies of Filipinos. Flery is hopeful that her businesses will grow and give them enough profits.

She dreams of having a house and a lot of her own. And in the near future, she is looking forward to buying a rickshaw to more easily transport her balot.

loans.use: Additional capital for "balot" selling and to pay for a videoke machine

loans.name: Maricar

texts.en: Maricar M. is a 28-year-old mother of one child. She has a sari-sari (variety) store business. She sells variety of goods to be able to raise funds to pay the family expenses. She started her business in 2008. Because of their growing needs, she also grows rice. She has a 1-hectare (2.5-acre) rice farm which helps supplement their income. She aspires to buy another hectare of land someday and to have a stable income for her family. She would like to ask a loan of Php 10,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to purchase additional merchandise for her sari-sari store. The loan will also help in maintaining their rice field. CEVI helps small businesses to grow. It provides not just loans but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To purchase additional merchandise and to maintain their rice field

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en:
Lilia B. is a 66 year-old woman who hails from the beautiful land of Antipolo City, the capital city of Rizal province in the Philippines. Her husband died years ago and left her with a daughter, Dina, who is now 43 years old and a college graduate. Lilia is a member of the Rizalwest Branch of ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines.

Considering her age, Lilia has invested the money from her loans in a general store in her village. The business brings her enough income for her day-today living. She is now requesting a loan amounting for 15,000 pesos for additional capital for her store.

She dreams of helping her grandchildren with their school expenses with savings from her business. She also still dreams that someday her general store will grow and become a grocery store.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her general store.

loans.name: Etyline

texts.en:
Etyline A. is a 30 year-old mother with a seven year-old daughter in elementary school named Carla. She is married to Cipriano, a 32 year-old construction worker. She resides in Antipolo, the capital city of Rizal Province in the Philippines. Antipolo is a mountainous city yet progressive and with beautiful views.

In 2004, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and a KIVA partner in the Philippines. She was motivated to join the institution to uplift her standard of living through access to capital for her business. She and her husband are partners in a business selling chicken. They also have secondary business processing and frying some of the chickens for sale in the village. Now on her 9th loan, Etyline is requesting a loan for 20,000 pesos as additional capital for both businesses.

Etyline is optimistic that her businesses will grow as they have for years. She is dreaming of sending her child to school through college. She also dreams of having a durable and concrete house of her own.

loans.use: To buy chickens and ingredients for fried chicken.

loans.name: Conchita

texts.en:
Conchita Z. is a native of Antipolo City, Rizal province in the Philippines. She is a 75 year-old widow striving on her own. At her age, Conchita is seen as a strong, old woman determined to uplift her standard of living.

In 2003, she joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines. She has utilized her loans in her primary business selling detergent soap and her secondary business selling fried chicken. Since she became a member of ASHI, she has been able to maintain very good performance. She is now requesting a loan for 25,000 pesos to use as additional capital for both businesses.

She still dreams of having a durable and concrete house of her own and save for her future because she is getting older now.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business selling detergent soap and to buy fried chicken ingredients.

loans.name: Kuyu

texts.en:
Kuyu L. sells cooking oil and charcoal and is requesting a loan to open a charcoal store. Kuyu is 49 years old and lost her husband in the 21 year liberation struggle for Southern Sudan. She has six children who all attend school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy tanks for water to sell.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To open a charcoal store.

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en:
Merlinda B. is a woman of great aspirations. She hails from the City of Antipolo, Rizal Province in the Philippines. She is 50 years old and married to a rickshaw driver, Randy. They have four children. All of the children reached college but are also all unemployed.

She is a member of Rizalwest Branch of ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines. She joined the institution in the 2007 with aspirations to uplift her standard of living. She runs a general store as her primary business and sells fried chicken as a secondary business. The businesses are of great help in their day-to-day living.

Now on her 4th loan, she is requesting 15,000 pesos as additional capital for her store and to buy ingredients for fried chicken.

She dreams of improving her housing and also her business performance in order to save for the the school needs of some of her children.

loans.use: To use as capital for her store and to pay for fried chicken ingredients.

loans.name: Vugar

texts.en:
"I am Vugar. You know me very well. I am applying for a Kiva loan for the second time. The first time, I applied for a Kiva loan of $1200 and with your help I improved my business. I am very thankful to Kiva and Kiva lenders."
In 2007, Vugar applied for his first Kiva loan. He has repaid this loan successfully. Now he needs a loan of 2000 AZN to buy spare parts for his car. He transports goods to the markets with this car.

loans.use: To buy spare parts for car

loans.name: Lilybeth

texts.en:
Lilybeth B. is a 27-year-old entrepreneur and mother of one child. She has a sari-sari ('various kinds') store business. She started a small store using her savings of 5,000 PHP. Every day she earned an average of 300 to 600 PHP from the store. This income enabled her to pay all her household expenses. Lilybeth is now requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP from Kiva partner, CEVI. She will use the loan to purchase additional merchandise for her store. The loan will help increase the capital size of her business.

About CEVI
CEVI helps small business to grow. It provides its clients not just with loans but with training and insurance cover as well.

loans.use: To purchase additional merchandise for her store

loans.name: Edgar

texts.en:
Edgar Barrientos is managing a piggery a short distance from his house. He is 36 years old and still single. He is working very hard to make his business flourish. He was a construction worker before. He stop working construction and decided to have a business to manage instead.
He would like a loan of 10,000 PHP from CEVI. He will use the loan to purchase pig feed and this will really help him grow his pig business. In this way, he will be able to save for his future family.
CEVI provides financial services to the poor--not just loans, but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To purchase pig feed

loans.name: Taleh

texts.en: Taleh has his own grocery store, and is requesting a loan of 2,000 AZN to buy more foodstuffs in order to improve his business. In 2006 he applied for his first loan of $1000 USD through Kiva, and he repaid this loan successfully. Now he is applying for his second loan through Kiva. He sends his thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs

loans.name: Lazu

texts.en:
Lazu C. is 39 years old and married. Her husband is a wildlife officer, and they have three children who are in school. Lazu currently sells tea. She is requesting a loan to stock more sugar and purchase chairs and tables for her restaurant. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a hotel.

About BRAC
BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted at returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase sugar, chairs and tables

loans.name: Nariman

texts.en:
"Hi dear friends. I think that you remember me. I am a taxi driver and you played a large role in improving my taxi business." Nariman is a taxi driver. In 2007, he applied to Kiva for a loan of US $1200 and with this loan he improved his business.
Now he has a problem with his car which he would like to repair. Nariman is applying for a second Kiva loan of 1200 AZN to buy spare parts to repair his car.

loans.use: To buy spare parts

loans.name: Siko

texts.en:
Siko T. is currently in the business of selling water and dresses and is requesting a loan to open up a shop and buy a sewing machine. Siko is 36 years old and is divorced. She has four children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To open up a shop and buy a sewing machine

loans.name: Gowo

texts.en:
Gowo J. is 42 years old and is married with a husband who is a chief. She has five school-aged children. Gowo prepares and sells food at her restaurant, and she is requesting a loan to purchase more rice and beans to be cooked in the restaurant. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to purchase some land, construct a building and rent it out.

About BRAC
BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted at returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase rice and beans for her restaurant

loans.name: Juan

texts.en:
Juan H. is 43 years old and married to a soldier. She has eight children who all go to school. Juan is currently in the business of selling eggs and bread, and is now requesting a loan to buy dresses and bedsheets to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay her children's school fees.

About BRAC
BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. loans.name: Levi

texts.en:
Levi D. is currently in the business of selling dresses, bedsheets and shoes and is requesting a loan to open up a store. Levi is 35 years old and is widowed. She has two children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to purchase land for the future of her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.name: Bayi

texts.en:
Bayi H. is 36 years old and married to a businessman. She has six children who all go to school. Bayi is currently in the business of selling charcoal from home and is now requesting a loan to build up a charcoal store at the market. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay her children's school fees.

About BRAC
BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted at returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To build up a charcoal store at the market

loans.name: Bi Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia is married with four sister-wives and has eight children. Lydia has seen death come unexpectedly when one of her children was bitten by a snake and died within four hours. In her small village of Baicham, in the hills of Belo, Cameroon, she uses her farm as a source of income for her family. With this loan, Lydia plans to pay for labor costs to clear and weed her farm. She will also use some of the money for home improvement.

Having been a farmer for many years, she knows that she will produce a successful crop with this money. She has already contributed 35,000 CFA (about $70) of her own money to these projects. For her house, she has already finished molding the bricks. By employing young adults to work on her farm, i.e. “stopping idleness,” she sees that she is helping the community.

With the profits from this loan, she will pay for her children’s school fees, improve her living conditions and increase her farm inputs. This is Lydia’s second loan from GHAPE since she became a beneficiary in 2008. Lydia takes out GHAPE loans because “GHAPE is out to help the poor” and she prefers paying back her loan in small instalments.

About GHAPE Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and a strong bond of trust has developed between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To pay labor costs for clearing and weeding farm

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en:
Caroline is married and has two young children. She lives in Tinkfuin, outside of Belo, Cameroon, and goes into town to sell her goods at Belo market. With this loan, Caroline will buy one bag of mixed beans, three bags of soybeans, and two bags of potatoes.

Caroline regards herself as a good businessperson – she attends to the customers at her market stall promptly, aims to keep her prices down, and treats her customers well. When she generates income with this loan, she will be able to employ workers on her farm, which she believes will help her community to prosper. Having faced poverty and been without food before, Caroline will use the profits from this loan to provide food for her children and pay for their school uniforms and stationery. She also will buy kitchen pots (made from aluminum).

This is Caroline’s second loan from Kiva partner, GHAPE, since she became a beneficiary in early 2007. Caroline takes out GHAPE loans because it teaches her how to do business. She believes that GHAPE grants loans to enable people to grow in their businesses.

About GHAPE
The Grounded and Holistic Approach for People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff, and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To purchase mixed beans, soy beans and potatoes

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca is married has two children. She lives in Acha, Cameroon, outside of a larger town of Belo, where she sells her goods. Using this loan, Rebecca will buy one tin of palm oil, 20 liters of kerosene, one bag of groundnuts (peanuts), 20 litres of groundnut oil, one carton of Baron (a popular boxed wine) and one carton of savon (soap).

With her stall in a good spot, Rebecca is confident in her ability to sell her goods. She is also very friendly to her customers, and to her regular customers, sells to them on credit. Being available is a priority for her, as she sees that to be advantageous in a busy market. The Belo market stretches for over two miles on a busy highway and a seller can easily blend in.

Rebecca recalls a time, in 1994, when she had a serious fall and was admitted to the hospital. That same year, she lost a child.

With the profits from this loan Rebecca will pay for her children’s school fees, try to increase her business by buying a machine that grinds a popular seed, Agusi, and promoting her business more.

This is Rebecca’s second loan from GHAPE since she became a beneficiary in 2007. Rebecca takes out GHAPE loans because of the small repayment installments as well as the opportunity to be more social, as GHAPE meets twice a month.

About GHAPE The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To buy inventory for market stall

loans.name: Mary Akwen

texts.en:
Mary is a widow who lives in Nsongwa, Cameroon, and has eight children. She has a farm, like many other people living in her area, and she sells the fruits of her labor in the Bamenda Food Market, about a ten minute drive from Nsongwa. Mary plans to buy cassava and potatoes for farming, manure to fertilize her fields, corn and pineapple. Mary also intends to purchase piglets and chickens. These animals can be useful as an investment and also as fertilizer for one’s farm. Lastly, Mary will buy some small garage tools.

Mary has been a farmer for many years and has experience using loans to fund her farm business. This is Mary’s fourth loan from GHAPE since she became a beneficiary in 2005. She knows from her past experience that she can take on a loan of this size and be successful.

Before she joined GHAPE, her life was very difficult. Her father passed when she was only 13, ending her education. She says she was forced to marry early and since then has lost her husband to a protracted illness leaving her to support her eight children. Mary was “financially not okay,” as she could not cover basic needs.

Mary is a GHAPE member because “GHAPE…empowers the poor” and “has trained me and equipped me with prosperous knowledge.” After being with GHAPE for three years, she has “discovered the benefits of being a GHAPE member.”

With the profits from this loan she will pay for her children’s school fees, provide the best for her children and finish the housing projects her husband left behind. She also wants to save a reasonable percentage in her GHAPE savings account.

About GHAPE Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and a strong bond of trust has developed between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: For cassava, potatoes, manure, corn, pineapples, pigs, chickens and garage tools

loans.name: Ngô Thị

texts.en:
H. Ngô Thị makes a living primarily from providing hairdressing and beauty services to local community members. She is a 38-year-old woman living in the town of Sóc Sơn. H. is married and has three school-aged children. She has been in business for over 12 years and earns approximately 6,000,000 VND a month.

In 1994, H. joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000,000 VND from TYM Fund. This previous loan was used to purchase materials for her business. H. is now requesting a loan of 20,000,000 VND which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be her fifteenth loan from TYM Fund.

No. 123940805.

loans.use: To invest in expanding a salon

loans.name: Hồ Thị

texts.en:
N. Hồ Thị (129011933) is a 41-year-old woman living in the town of Sóc Sơn. She is married and has 2 school-aged children. To making a living, N. owns & operates a business venture in the food sector running a food stall. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling dried goods in the local community. N. has been engaged in this business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,000,000 Vietnamese Dong (about US $277) a month from these activities.

In 1994, N. joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. N. has successfully repaid a previous loan from TYM Fund. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. N. is now requesting a new loan of 20,000,000 VND which will be 129011933. The loan will be the 15th loan taken out by the borrower from TYM Fund. N. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.use: Business capital

loans.name: Nhữ Thị Nguyệt

texts.en:
N. Nhữ Thị Nguyệt makes a living primarily from raising pigs to sell. She is a 63-year-old woman living in the town of Sóc Sơn. N. is married and has 3 adult children. She has been in business for over eight years and earns approximately 5,500,000 VND a month.

In 1998, N. joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000,000 VND from TYM Fund. This previous loan was used to build a shelter for the her livestock. N. is now requesting a loan of 20,000,000 VND which will be used to purchase breeding livestock. This will be her tenth loan from TYM Fund. N. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to expand her business.

No. 139011933.

loans.use: To purchase breeding livestock

loans.name: Phạm Thị

texts.en:
T. Phạm Thị (121010737) is a 51-year-old female living in the town of Sóc Sơn. She is married and has three adult children. 

T. owns and operates a restaurant, serving a variety of different meals to customers in the local community. T. has been engaged in this business for over 20 years and earns approximately 5,000,000 VND a month.

In 2001, T. joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. T. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000,000 VND from TYM Fund. This previous loan was used to purchase food and drinks for the restaurant.

T. is now requesting a new loan of 20,000,000 VND which will be used to invest in expanding the business. The loan will be her 9th loan from TYM Fund. T. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Nguyễn Thị

texts.en:

While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing general services to local community members.  T. has been engaged in this business for more than five years and earns approximately 5,500,000 VND a month from these activities.


In 2001, T. joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  T. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000,000 VND from TYM Fund.  This previous loan was used to invest in renovating her business.  T. is now requesting a new loan of 20,000,000 VND (US$1,175), which will be used to invest in expanding the business.  The loan will be the eighth loan taken out by the borrower from TYM Fund.  T. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Nguyễn Thị

T. is now requesting a new loan of 20,000,000 VND which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. The loan will be her 6th loan from TYM Fund. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Cao Thị

texts.en:
T. Cao Thị (2320800006) is a 40-year-old female living in the town of Kim Động. She is married and has three school-aged children.

T. works in a family member's business manufacturing and selling incense products to local businesses and community members. She has just started operating this business and earns approximately 3,000,000 VND a month.

In 2008, T. joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from TYM Fund. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business.

T. is now requesting a new loan of 9,000,000 VND which will be used to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products. The loan will be her 2nd loan from TYM Fund. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products

loans.name: Nguyễn Thị

texts.en:
T. Nguyễn Thị (2320080713) is a 57-year-old female living in the town of Kim Động. She is married and has four adult children.

T. owns and operates a business cultivating fruit trees and harvesting its fruit for sale. She has just started operating this business and earns approximately 3,000,000 VND a month.

In 2008, T. joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from TYM Fund. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business.

T. is now requesting a new loan of 9,000,000 VND which will be used to pay for services to increase crop yield. The loan will be her 2nd loan from TYM Fund. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business

loans.use: To pay for services to increase crop yield

loans.name: Lê Thị Thu

texts.en:
H. Lê Thị Thu (2320080712) is a 32-year-old female living in the town of Kim Động. She is married and has two infant children.

H. owns and operates a business raising chickens for sale. She has just started operating this business and earns approximately 2,500,000 VND a month.

In 2008, H. joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from TYM Fund. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business.

H. is now requesting a new loan of 9,000,000 VND which will be used to purchase breeding livestock. The loan will be her 2nd loan from TYM Fund. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase breeding livestock

loans.name: Nkwenti

texts.en: L. is a single mother of three children. She has a farm where she grows vegetables to sell at the Bamenda Food Market, about ten minutes into town. With this loan, L. will pay her farm rent, pay for labor to clear and weed her farm, buy four bags of fertilizer, about 14,000 CFA’s (about $28’s) worth of seeds, a piglet, a chicken, animal feed and huckleberry (green vegetable) seeds for planting. Having been a farmer already and seen that she can sell her produce, L. is confident she will do well with this loan. As well, while raising her pigs and fowls, she will be able to sell the manure as fertilizer. In the end, she knows that residents in her community will buy her grown pigs and fowl. After the age of 6, when her father passed away, it was hard for L. to afford to go to school. Since then, she has raised her children without a partner, and has financial difficulties because of that. With the profits from this loan she will pay for her children’s school fees, feed her family, put money towards building her house and be prepared to help her family with health problems. This is L.’s third loan from GHAPE since she became a beneficiary in 2006. L. takes out GHAPE loans because they give training on how to use her loan. About GHAPE The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profit and loss, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To use for farmland rent, to pay for labor to clear land, plus to buy many items for her business

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph N. runs a provisions store by the roadside in his community. He also deals mainly in bags of sugar. He procures bags of sugar and other groceries from supermarkets in surrounding bigger towns and also from vans that come round to distribute. Joseph has been in business for over thirty years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk to increase his stock.

Joseph is 65 years old, married and has eight children: six sons and two daughters. Some of his children are currently in senior high, junior high and primary schools. Others are out of school and working. His wife is a trader. Joseph lives with his wife and children in a family house in Suhum, a town in Ghana. Suhum is a busy business centre in the Eastern Region. The majority of the inhabitants are into one type of business activity or another.

loans.use: To buy provisions to sell

loans.name: Patience

texts.en:
Patience K. is sixty-three years old and is widowed. She lost her husband barely one month ago and is still in the period of mourning - hence, her dark-colored clothes. She has six children to cater for: three sons and three daughters. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in a commercial town called Suhum in the Eastern Region of Ghana.

Patience works very hard to provide for the family. She is a trader and trades in vegetables. She buys her goods such as peppers, tomatoes, onions, etc. from surrounding farming communities. She sells in a kiosk in the market square and also treks to other towns to sell on their market days.

Patience has been in business for ten years now and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk so that she can expand her business. She is hopeful to give her children a good education.

loans.use: To buy vegetables in bulk

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice Atta-Brayo is fifty years old, married, and has given birth to four children: one son and three daughters. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a commercial town called Suhum in the Eastern Region of Ghana. Beatrice works very hard to support her husband financially to provide for the family. Her husband is a mason by profession.

Beatrice is a trader, trading in cosmetics. She buys her goods such as powder, pomades, body cream, lotion, body spray, etc. from Accra and hawks (sells door-to-door) to sell in her community. She also treks to other towns to sell on their market days. Beatrice has been in business for barely a year now and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk so that she can expand her business.

loans.use: To buy cosmetics in bulk

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en:
Christiana M. is forty-two years old, married, and has given birth to three children: two sons and a daughter. According to her, all are still in school: one is in the junior high while the others are in the primary school. Christiana lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a commercial town called Suhum in the Eastern Region of Ghana. She works very hard to help her husband provide for the family. Her husband is a farmer.

Christiana is a trader and runs a provisions store in her community. Her shop is by the road side. She buys the groceries from Accra and other big shops in her community. She has been in business for five years and wants a loan to buy provisions in bulk so that she can increase her stock. She is hopeful to sponsor her children in school to high levels.

loans.use: To buy provisions in bulk

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther C. is fifty years old, married, and has given birth to three children:  two sons and a daughter. According to her, all are still in school: one is in the junior high while the others are in the primary school. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a commercial town called Suhum in the Eastern Region of Ghana.

Esther works very hard to help her husband provide for the family. She is a trader, and runs a provisions store in her community. Her shop is on one of the streets. She buys the groceries from Accra and other big shops in her community.

Esther has been in business for sixteen years and wants a loan to buy provisions in bulk so that she can increase her stock. She is hopeful to sponsor her children in school to higher levels.

loans.use: To buy provisions in bulk

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel T. is forty-two years old, married, and has three children: two sons and a daughter who are all currently in school – junior high and primary schools. He lives with his wife and children in a rented apartment in a town in Ghana called Suhum. Suhum is a busy business centre in the Eastern Region. The majority of the inhabitants are into one particular type of business activity or another. Samuel’s wife trades to support him financially. She trades in vegetables.

Samuel runs a drinks bar, selling soft drinks such as Fanta, Coke, Pepsi, Sprite, etc. He buys his drinks from the distributers who come round to supply in vans. Samuel has been in business for six years and wants a loan to procure drinks in bulk to increase his stock. He is hopeful to give his children the best education he can afford.

loans.use: To buy soft drinks in bulk

loans.name: Seth

texts.en:
Seth O. is thirty-two years old, married, and has three children: two sons and a daughter who are all currently in the junior high and primary schools. He lives with his wife and children in a rented apartment in a town in Ghana called Suhum. Suhum is a busy business centre in the Eastern Region. The majority of the inhabitants are into one particular type of business activity or another. His wife runs a provision store to support him financially.

Seth runs a pharmacy in his community. He buys his drugs from the distributers who come round to supply in vans. He has been in business for over fifteen years and wants a loan to procure drugs in bulk to increase his stock. He is hopeful to give his children the best education.

loans.use: To procure drugs in bulk

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel O. is forty-nine years old, married, and has five children: three sons and two daughters who are all currently in school – senior high, junior high and primary school. He lives with his wife and children in a rented apartment in a town in Ghana called Suhum, a busy business centre in the Eastern Region. The majority of the inhabitants are into one particular type of business activity or another. His wife trades to support him financially.

Emmanuel runs a pharmacy shop in his community. He buys his drugs from the distributers who come round to supply in vans. He has been in business for over twenty-three years and wants a loan to procure drugs in bulk to increase his stock. He is hopeful to give his children the best education.

loans.use: To procure drugs in bulk

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel M. is forty-two years old, married, and has two children: a boy and a girl who are both currently in the primary school. He lives with his wife and children in a rented apartment in a town in Ghana called Suhum, a busy business centre in the Eastern Region. The majority of the inhabitants are into one particular type of business activity or another. His wife trades to support him financially.

Emmanuel trades in salt and dried pepper. He buys from the distributers from other towns and sells to retailers and food vendors in his community. He has been in business for five years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk to increase his stock.

loans.use: To buy bags of salt in bulk

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace K. is forty years old, divorced, and has two children: a boy and a girl. According to her, both are still in school: one is in the junior high while the other is in the primary school. Grace lives with her children in a rented apartment in a commercial town called Suhum in the Eastern Region of Ghana.

Grace works very hard to provide for the family. She is a trader and runs a provisions store in her community. Her shop is on one of the streets. Grace buys the groceries from Accra and other big shops in her community. She has been in business for twelve years and wants a loan buy provisions in bulk so that she can increase her stock. Grace is hopeful to sponsor her children in school to greater heights.

loans.use: To buy provisions in bulk

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys A. is thirty-three years old, married, and currently has no child. She lives with her husband in a rented apartment in a commercial town called Suhum in the Eastern Region of Ghana. Her husband deals in secondhand vehicle tires.

Gladys works very hard to support her husband financially. She is a trader and trades in secondhand clothes for women. She buys her goods from Accra and hawks (sells door-to-door) to sell in her community. She also treks to other towns to sell on their market days. She has been in business for four years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk so that she can expand her business.

loans.use: To buy secondhand clothes in bulk

loans.name: Eva

texts.en:
Eva A. is a food vendor. She runs a chop bar in her locality. She serves local dishes like fufu from cassava, banku from corn dough, etc. She sells from morning till evening. Eva has been in business for three years. She buys foodstuffs such as cassava, maize, vegetables and other ingredients from surrounding towns.

Eva is 23 years old, married and has two sons. According to her, both are currently in primary school. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in the commercial town of Suhum, in the Eastern Region of Ghana. Eva works very hard to help her husband provide for the family.

loans.use: To buy foodstuff

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en:
Juliana S. bakes bread for sale. She distributes to retailers and beverage sellers in her community. She buys bags of flour and other ingredients from Koforidua, the regional capital.
She is 60 years old, divorced and has given birth to two sets of twins, both sons. Her children have completed school and are currently working. Juliana lives with her daughter-in-law in a house in the commercial town of Suhum, in the Eastern Region of Ghana.
Juliana works very hard to provide for her family. She has been in business for over 26 years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk so she can expand her business.

loans.use: To buy bags of flour

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria A. is thirty years old. She is married and has given birth to five children. All are currently in primary school. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a commercial town called Suhum in the Eastern Region of Ghana. Victoria works very hard to support her husband and to provide for the family. Her husband is a fisherman. She is a fish monger. Victoria buys fresh fish from nearby stores and smokes them herself. She also fries some of the fish and sells it on a tray in the lorry station. She also distributes to retailers and food vendors in her community. Victoria has been in business for two years and wants a loan buy fresh fish in bulk so she can increase her stock. She is hopeful to be able  to send her children to higher levels in school.

loans.use: To buy fresh fish

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice A. is forty years old. She is married and has given birth to three children. All are currently in school. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a commercial town called Suhum in the Eastern Region of Ghana. Alice works very hard to support her husband and to provide for the family. Her husband trades in foot wear. She is a trader. She deals in eggs. Alice buys crates of eggs from poultry farms in nearby communities and sells in the market square. She also distributes to retailers. 
She has been in business for over fourteen years and wants a loan buy eggs in bulk so she can increase her stock. Alice is hopeful to be able to afford to send her children to the highest levels in school.

loans.use: To buy crates of eggs

loans.name: Chris

texts.en: Chris L. is thirty-five years old. He is married and has two children, a boy and a girl who are both currently in the primary school. Chris lives with his wife and children in a rented apartment in a town in Ghana called Suhum. Suhum is a busy business centre in the Eastern Region. His wife trades to help him financially. He runs a provision store by the road side in his community. Chris procures groceries such as tins of milk and Milo, bags of sugar, candies, soap, etc. from big supermarkets in the surrounding towns and also from vans that come round to distribute. He has been in business for fifteen years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk to increase his stock.

loans.use: To buy provisions in bulk

loans.name: Primavera Ii Group

texts.es: Hace mas de cinco años, dieciséis mujeres conforman la asociación “Primavera II”, están convencidas que con una actividad propia pueden mejorar su calidad de vida. La mayoría de ellas viven en la zona Villa Tejada, de la ciudad de El Alto. Diversas son las actividades de este grupo, venden; CDs, verduras, frutas, material de escritorio, cosméticos, otras también realizan confección de polleras (Una pollera es una falda larga usada como vestimenta femenina, típica en algunas regiones de Bolivia). La asociación Primavera II, afirman que la constante elevación de precios en artículos de primera necesidad causo desequilibrio económico en sus hogares, por lo que necesitan créditos para comprar mayor cantidad de productos, para ampliar sus  negocios y poder obtener mayores ganancias.
texts.en:
Five years ago 16 women formed the group "Primavera II" and they were convinced that working for themselves could help them to improve their quality of life. The majority of the women live in the Villa Tejada neighborhood in the city of El Altos. They make livings by doing a variety of activities which include, selling CD's, vegetables, fruits, writing materials, cosmetics. Others make a living by making "polleras" (these are a long skirt worn by the women in some areas of Bolivia). The Primavera II say that the constant increase of the prices of basic needs items causes hardship in their homes. Therefore, they need loans to buy products in bulk and at wholesale prices so that they can help to grow their business and increase their profits.

(Translated by Alexis of San Roque High School)

Translated from Spanish by San Roque School, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy products in bulk and at wholesale prices so that they can help to grow their business and increase their profits

loans.name: Villa Alto Pura Pura Group

texts.es:
La asociación “Villa Alto Pura Pura” pertenece al centro focal Alto Lima, con la ayuda de su asistente de créditos trabajan muy responsables en todas sus actividades de grupo.
Casi todas casadas, con familias numerosas nos cuentan que los gastos diarios que tienen en sus hogares sobrepasan al ingreso que obtienen en sus negocios ya que sus hijos van creciendo y tienen  mayores necesidades.
La mayor parte del grupo se dedica a  comercio, de variados productos, venta que la realizan en puestos fijos y también de  forma ambulante, por ejemplo, venden golosinas y chocolates, productos de limpieza, calzados, medias, celulares y otros. Ahora ellas quieren mejorar sus venta, para esto necesitan de mayor capital para poder comprar mercadería al por mayor. De esta manera  mejorarían sus ingresos, por lo tanto también la  estabilidad económica en sus hogares.
texts.en:
The Villa Alto Pura Pura Asociacion belongs to group Alto Lima. With the help of their loan assistant they work very responsibly in all their activities as a group. Almost all of the members are married, with various working familiy members that help to ensure that their daily expenses does not surpass the income that receive from their business. Their children are growing and have greater needs but they are still able to provide for them. Most of the group members make a living as merchants selling goods like chocolates, products for cleaning, footwear, socks and pantyhose, cellular phones and other items. Now they want to improve their profits and sales by purchasing wholesale merchandise. This way they will be able to increase their income and contribute to financial stability for their families.

(Translated by Katie of San Roque High School)

Translated from Spanish by San Roque School, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase wholesale merchandise

loans.name: Kantutas Group

texts.es:
En la zona Huayna Potosí de la ciudad de El Alto se encuentra ubicado el centro focal Germán Buch, a este pertenece la asociación “Kantutas” integrado por once miembros, la mayoría viven en la misma zona siendo así el grupo formado entre vecinos amigos y familia.
Son varias las actividades que realiza la asociación “Kantutas”, .por ejemplo Dionicia, que es la presidente del grupo se dedica a la venta de muebles,otras de las socias venden chompas, abrigos, vídeos,cosmeticos, bisutería, material escolar y otros. Ahora con la llegada del invierno, la adquisición de ropa especial para este clima aumento, por eso quieren comprar ropa y accesorios adecuados,  están seguras que obtendrán mayores ventas y sus ganancias serán mejores.
texts.en:
In the neighborhood of Huayna Potosi located in the city of El Alto, there is a group called German Buch which belongs to the "Kantutas" association. There are eleven members in the group. The majority of the members live in the same neighborhood and are neighbors and family members. The members make a living by doing several different activities. For example Dionicia, who is the president of the group, sells furniture, and other members sell sweaters, videos, cosmetics, jewelry, clothing, material etc. Now with the coming of winter in the Southern Hemisphere they want to buy clothes that they can sell to keep people warm during the winter season. That is why they want the money to buy the clothes and accessories so they can sell them and they are sure that their sales and income will increase.

(Translated by Alexis of San Roque High School)

Translated from Spanish by San Roque School, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Renacer Group

texts.es:
El centro focal Germán Buch esta ubicado en la  ciudad de El Alto, a este pertenece la asociación "Renacer”, trabajan hace un año junto a la familia de Pro-mujer, con mucha responsabilidad en cuanto a sus cuotas de crédito y actividades internas.
Diferentes son los negocios que existen en este grupo, algunas se dedican a la costura; otras realizan confección de calzados; tejido a mano de chompas y mantillas, una de ellas tiene su taller de cerrajería. Actualmente desean aumentar su producción para vender sus productos a tiendas comerciales, por lo que necesitan mayor capital, para la adquisición de materia prima. Tienen la seguridad  de mejorar sus ingresos, de esta manera mejorar también la calidad de vida de sus familias
texts.en:
The central focus of German Buch is located in the city of El Alto, which pertains to the “Renacer” [Reborn] association. They have worked together over the last year with the “Pro-Mujer” [Pro-Woman] group and have been very responsible when it comes to their loan payments and internal activities. The businesses in this group are diverse, some are dedicated to sewing, others make shoes, or hand woven sweaters and shawls. One of the women has her own locksmith shop. Currently, they want to increase their production of sellable goods to increase profits in order to buy more primary materials. This will surely increase their profits and therefore improve their families’ quality of life as well.

Translated from Spanish by Andrea Kellogg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase primary materials

loans.name: Olindo

texts.es: Olindo es un hombre muy activo y trabajador, tiene 41 años, es soltero y vive en una casa alquilada, él tiene muchas ganas de mejorar su vida y salir adelante. Recorrer con su taxi las calles de Juliaca constituye su forma de ganarse la vida, sale todos los días en busca de personas que deseen llegar de manera rápida y segura a su destino. Su taxi por lo general está ocupado, ya que su habilidad o suerte como lo llama él, para encontrar pasajeros han hecho que su trabajo le genere los ingresos necesarios para cubrir sus gastos. Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es manejar, lleva 13 años en esta actividad, y la experiencia lo ha llevado a  conocer cada jirón, avenida y calle de su ciudad. Para un futuro cercano, espera comprar un auto nuevo y ponerlo a trabajar en la misma empresa de taxi, Olindo considera que lo más difícil es trabajar de madrugada, ya que tiene que soportar el intenso frió, el cual hace las noches más largas. Este es su primer préstamo con MFP, sabe que tiene que pagar todas sus cuotas a tiempo y está dispuesto a hacerlo, en su banco comunal es muy responsable, ya que no quiere causarle problemas a sus compañeros. Los mil nuevos soles solicitados los invertirá en reparar algunos desperfectos de su taxi, para así brindarles un mejor servicio a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Olindo is a very active and hardworking man. He is 41 years old, is single, and lives in a rented home. He is very motivated to improve his life and to move forward.

To earn an income, he drives his taxi through the streets of Juliaca. He goes out everyday in search of people who wish to arrive quickly and securely at their destinations. His taxi is usually occupied, such that his ability (or luck as he calls it) to find passengers has made his business able to generate the income necessary to cover his expenses.

What he likes the best about his job is driving. He has 13 years of experience with this activity, and this experience has helped him to get to know each street, avenue, and ally of his city.

For the near future, he hopes to buy a new car and to put it to work as a taxi. Olindo considers the most difficult time to work the very early morning as he has to withstand the intense cold, which makes the nights much longer.

This is his first loan with MFP, and he knows that he needs to pay all of his installments on time and he is ready to do so. In his community bank, he is very responsible, as he doesn't want to cause trouble for the other members. The 1000 Peruvian Soles he seeks he will invest in the repair of some imperfections in his taxi, and therefore be able to offer better service to his clients.

Translated from Spanish by Michelle Harrison, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Repair of his taxi

loans.name: Sandra

texts.es: Sandra es una joven de 18 años muy trabajadora, vive de manera independiente en una casa alquilada, y está dispuesta a trabajar duro con tal de salir adelante y mejorar su vida. El canto le ha dado la oportunidad de progresar, ella es cantante folcklorica y aunque es muy joven, va en camino de ganarse un buen nombre en esta profesión, a su corta edad sabe lo que es viajar por los diferentes distritos de Puno sin tener tiempo ni para dormir, puesto que en las fiestas patronales todos esperan escuchar a “Duvani la Cariñosita de Amor”. Aunque su nombre es Sandra, ha escogido “Duvani”, su segundo nombre, para promocionarse, es por eso que entre sus amistades y vecinos es más conocida como Duvani. Le gusta mucho cantar y deleitar a la gente con su linda voz, empezó cuando tenía tan sólo 10 años como bailarina de otras cantantes folclóricas, y ahora ya lleva 8 años en esta actividad. Sandra tiene los deseos de hacerse popular y llegar a ser muy famosa, tal vez como Sonia Morales (cantante folclórica muy reconocida en su país), quien es su modelo a seguir. Este es su primer préstamo con MFP, sabe que tiene que pagarlo a tiempo y está dispuesta a ahorrar en cada viaje para lograrlo, es una socia muy alegre en su banco comunal y es muy querida por sus compañeras. Los mil nuevos soles solicitados los invertirá en la grabación de su nuevo disco, con el cual espera hacerse más conocida.
texts.en:
Sandra is a hardworking 18-year-old who lives on her own in a rented house. She is willing to work hard in order to get ahead and improve her life. Singing has given her the opportunity to progress in life. She is a folk singer, and even though she is very young, she is on the road to making a name for herself in this profession. At her young age, she has already traveled through the different districts of Puno without even having time to sleep because everyone is waiting to see “Duvani la Cariñosita de Amor” at all the patron saint celebrations. Even though her name is Sandra, she goes by Duvani, her middle name, to promote herself. That is why she is known as Duvani among her friends and neighbors. She really loves to sing and delight people with her beautiful voice. She started out as a back-up dancer for other folk singers at age 10, and she has now been in show business for 8 years. Sandra hopes to become famous, perhaps as famous as Sonia Morales (a well-known folk singer in the country), who is her role model. This is her first loan with MFP. She knows that she must repay the loan on time and is willing to save money on each tour to pay it back. She is a very cheerful member in her microfinance institute, and is well-loved by the other group members. She will use the 1,000.00 PEN loan to record a new album, which she hopes will make her more popular.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Record an album

loans.name: Víctor

texts.es: Víctor tiene 32 años, es soltero y vive en una casa alquilada, es muy atento y preocupado, y tiene muchas ganas forjarse un buen futuro. Todos los días, acompañado de su camioneta (combi), sale muy temprano de su casa, dadas las 5 de la mañana, ya tiene que estar formado en espera a que su línea de transportes le de la orden para salir. Su ruta es la número 19 y es una de las más difíciles para cubrir, ya que la gran cantidad de pasajeros, junto al mal estado de las carreteras, hacen que tenga que hacer un mayor esfuerzo. Lo que más le gusta a Víctor es conducir, es por eso que a la edad de 25 años decidió, con la ayuda de sus padres, comprar una combi, la cual hasta ahora lo acompaña. Él considera que lo más difícil de su trabajo es tener que lidiar con algunas personas que no quieren pagarle o le pagan menos de la tarifa regular, aun así sabe que ese es su trabajo y que tiene que realizarlo, poniéndole todo su empeño. Este es su primer préstamo con MFP, y está muy contento por la oportunidad de obtenerlo, ya que piensa invertirlo bien, en su banco comunal es un socio muy respetado, debido a que siempre pone orden en el grupo. Con los mil nuevos soles que solicita comprará nuevas llantas para su combi y así podrá brindar un mejor servicio a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Víctor is a 32-year-old single man who lives in a rented home. He is very attentive and concerned, and he has a great desire to shape a good future for himself. Everyday, he leaves his house with his van (VW bus) at around 5 in the morning because he has to wait for his transportation line to give him the orders to leave. His route is number 19, which is one of the most difficult ones to cover because of the large amount of passengers and the bad road conditions, so he has to make a big effort. What Victor most likes is driving, which is why he decided to buy a VW bus (which he is still using) at age 25 with the help of his parents. He thinks that the most difficult part of his job is dealing with people who do not want to pay, or who pay a less than the normal fare. Even so, he knows that this is his job and he has to give it his all. This is his first loan with MFP, and he is very happy for this opportunity to receive one because he is planning to invest it well. He is a very well-respected member of his microfinance institute because he always establishes order in the group. With the 1,000.00 PEN loan that he is requesting, he will purchase new tires for his vehicle so that he can offer better services to his customers.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase tires for his van

loans.name: Apolinario

texts.en:
Apolinario S. is the father of two children: Mark Lester and Erika Mae. Managing his passenger tricycle is his daily source of income for his family while his wife, Eliza, works as a domestic helper in Dubai. They are both working patiently to have a progressive family and provide a better life for their children.

Apolinario wanted to borrow PHP 6,000 for the maintenance of his motorcycle. He will purchase parts and accessories it needs for a better transport operation. He always finds ways to help his wife earn a living and not to depend on her monthly salary abroad. He prays that Kiva lenders will provide him the financial support he is requesting and that his business will be fruitful for the welfare of his family.

loans.use: To maintain his motorcycle

loans.name: Divina

texts.en:
Hog raising is the simple business chosen by Divina R.. She is the mother of three children and finds difficulties in providing them with their school fees. Aside from raising hogs, she also raises ducks and engages in an egg-vending business.  She is really thankful for having her small enterprises for it helps her in providing the needs of her family. She wants to pursue her livelihood for her family for it really helps her financially.

She would like to request a loan of PHP 6,000 to make her business grow. She is used to delivering eggs as early as 5:00 in the morning and after that, she takes care of her livestock. Her dream is to improve their poor living condition and someday to become successful in the business.

loans.use: To use as business capital

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
With his desire to have a good quality of life, Richard tries and does his best in managing his computer shop business that provides his family, especially his parents, with their basic necessities. Richard is 28 years old and still single. He worked abroad for three years until he decided to come home and put up his own business.

However, due to lack of capital to maintain his business, Richard is requesting a loan of PHP 7,000. His dream is to become a successful businessman someday and to have a family of his own.

loans.use: To use as business capital

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan generates her daily income through her food-vending business. Her husband, Ely, is working abroad so she serves as the mother and father to their children. She finds the task very difficult but, according to her, she needs to be patient and must sacrifice everything for their family.

She manages a humble eatery business in their village. She hopes that her business will grow and have high profit to help her husband in providing for the needs of their family. She wanted to borrow a loan from lenders amounting to PHP 7,000 as additional working capital to make her vending bigger and more sustainable.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital

loans.name: Maria Asuncion

texts.es:
La señora Maria Asunción A. B. tiene 50 años, vive en el distrito de la Esperanza, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Ella estudió Primaria completa,  tiene 2  hijos de 14 y 15 años, que depende económicamente de ella.
Maria se dedica a la venta de comida, este negocio se inicio hace 2 años,  su negocio lo desarrolla en su casa.
Su primer crédito de 300 soles que recibió de su Banco comunal Bellavista  II, lo invirtió en implementar su ferreteria la misma que su hijo lo administra en tacorita.
El crédito de 500 soles, lo invertirá  en implementar su ferreteria  y remodelar sus utencillos de cocina para la venta de su comida.
Maria tiene como sueño tener su ferreteria mas implementada para crecer como microempresaria.
texts.en:
Mrs. Maria Asuncion A. B. is 50 years old, and lives in the district of Esperenza, in the province of Trujillo, in the district of La Libertad, in Peru. Maria finished grade school, and has two children, a 14 and a 15 year old, who depend on her economically. Maria has run a business selling food out of her home for the past two years. She received her first loan of 300 soles from the community bank Bellavista II, and invested it in starting a hardware store like the one her son runs in Tacorita. She will invest this loan of 500 soles in fixing up her hardware store and getting better kitchen utensils for preparing the food that she sells. Maria dreams of further setting up her hardware store so she can grow as a small business woman.

Translated from Spanish by Cyrus Maher, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: fix up hardware store and buy kitchet utensils

loans.name: Maria Teresa

texts.es:
La señora Maria Teresa B. D. Gastañadui tiene 62 años, vive en el distrito D. la Esperanza, provincia D. Trujillo, departamento D. La Libertad, Perú.
Ella estudió secundaria completa, no tiene hijos que depenD. económicamente D. ella.
Teresa se dedica a la venta D. productos D. pan llevar, el negocio se inicio hace un años, antes se dedicaba a la elaboración D. carteras tejidas, su negocio lo desarrolla en su casa.
Su primer crédito D. 300 soles que recibió D. su Banco comunal Bellavista  II, lo invirtió en la compra D. hilo, cintas para elaborar sus carteras y almohadas.
El crédito D. 500 soles, lo invertirá en la compra D. insumos (arroz, azúcar, pan) para incrementar su bodega.
Teresa tiene como sueño tener su propio un minimarket  para crecer como microempresaria.
texts.en:
Maria Teresa B. D. Gastanadui is 62 years old and lives in the district of Esperanza, in the province of Trujillo, in the department of La Libertad, in Peru. She finished high school, and does not have children who depend on her economically. Teresa has sold bread products for the past year, and before that she worked out of her home making woven purses. She received her first loan of 300 soles from the community bank of Bellavista II, which she invested in the purchase of thread and ribbons for making her purses and pillows. She will invest the loan of 500 soles in the purchase of food items such as rice, sugar, and bread in order to expand the small store that she runs. Teresa's dream is to have her own mini-mart in order to keep growing as a small businesswoman.

Translated from Spanish by Cyrus Maher, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of food items

loans.name: Yrene

texts.es:
La señora Yrene C. L. tiene 54 años, vive en el distrito de la Esperanza, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Ella estudió secundaria completa, tiene 1 hijo que depende económicamente de ella.
Yrene se dedica a la venta de comida y sandalias, inicio su negocio vendiendo comida en el mercado hace 25 años, su negocio lo desarrolla en el mercado de Bellavista.
Con su primer crédito de 300 soles que recibió de su Banco comunal Bellavista  II, lo invirtió en la compra de carnes y verduras (carne de carnero, gallina, repollo, cebolla, etc.) para preparar la comida.
El crédito de 500 soles, lo invertirá en la compra de sandalias, zapatillas y ropa interior para implementar su puesto de ropa.
Yrene tiene como sueño tener su tienda de ropa  para crecer como microempresaria.
texts.en:
Yrene C. L. is 54 years old, and lives in the district of Esperanza, in the province of Trujillo, in the department of La Libertad, Peru. She finished high school and has one child who depends on her economically. For the past 25 years, Yrene has run a business selling food and sandals in the market in Bellavista. Yrene received her first loan of 300 soles from the community bank Bellavista II, and invested that money in the purchase of meats and vegetables (ram meat, chicken, cabbage, onion, etc.) so that she could prepare meals from those ingredients. She will invest this loan of 500 soles in the purchase of sandals, slippers, and underwear in order to expand the clothing items that she offers. Yrene dreams of having a clothing store in order to keep growing as a small businesswoman.

Translated from Spanish by Cyrus Maher, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of clothing items

loans.name: Francisca

texts.es:
La señora Francisca C. C. tiene 55 años, vive en el distrito D. la Esperanza, provincia D. Trujillo, departamento D. La Libertad, Perú.
Ella estudió Primaria  Incompleta, tiene  2 hijos que depenD. económicamente D. ella.
Francisca se dedica a la venta bebidas y golosinas, este negocio se inicio hace 1 años,  su negocio en afueras del complejo deportivo y recreacional D. Bellavista.
Su primer crédito D. 300 soles que recibió D. su Banco comunal Bellavista  II, lo invertirá en la compra D. productos como gaseosas y golosinas.
Francisca tiene como sueño tener su bodega mas implementada  para crecer como microempresaria.
texts.en:
Francisca C. C. is 55 years old, lives in the district "la Esperanza" ["the Hope"] in the province of Trujillo in the department of La Libertad, Peru. She didn't finish elementary school. She has two children that depend on her financially. Francisca dedicates herself to selling drinks and sweets. She began this business a year ago. Her business is outsiD. the sports and recreation complex in Bellavista. Her first loan of 300 soles that she received from the community bank Bellavista II, she will invest in purchasing products such as soft drinks and sweets. Francisca's dream is to have her grocery store better set up in order to grow as a micro-enterprise.

Translated from Spanish by Anne Rodriguez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy products such as soft drinks and sweets

loans.name: Lucia Yuri

texts.es:
La señora Lucia Yuri F. Sánchez  tiene 24 años, vive en el distrito de la Esperanza, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Ella estudió primaria incompleta, tiene 1 hijo que depende económicamente de ella.
Lucia  se dedica a la venta de bebidas gaseosas y cerveza, el negocio se inicio hace un años,  su negocio lo desarrolla en su casa.
Su primer crédito de 200 soles que recibió de su Banco comunal Bellavista  II, lo invirtió en la compra de gaseosas y cerveza.
El crédito de 700 soles, lo invertirá en la compra de insumos (arroz, azúcar, pan) y bebidas como gaseosas, para incrementar su bodega.
Teresa tiene como sueño tener su propio minimarket  para crecer como microempresaria.
texts.en:
Lucia Yuri F. Sánchez is 24 years old, lives in the district of "la Esperanza" ["the Hope"] in the province of Trujillo in the department of La Libertad, Peru. She did not finish elementary school.
