She has a son that depends on her financially. Lucia dedicates herself to selling soft drinks and beer. She began this business a few years ago and developed it in her home. She invested her first loan of 200 soles that she received from her community bank Bellavista II in purchasing soft drinks and beer. She will invest the loan of 700 soles in purchasing supplies (rice, sugar, bread) and drinks such as soft drinks, to increase the size of her grocery store. Teresa's dream is to have her own mini-market to grow as a micro-enterprise.

Translated from Spanish by Anne Rodriguez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy supplies (rice, sugar, bread) and drinks such as soft drinks to increase the size of her grocery store

loans.name: Elsy Elizabeth

texts.es:
La señora Elsy Elizabeth G. A.  tiene 28 años, vive en el distrito de la Esperanza, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Ella estudió primaria incompleta, tiene 3 hijos que depende económicamente de ella.
Elsy se dedica a la venta de ropa y productos del pan llevar, inicio su negocio vendiendo abarrotes en su casa, hace dos años y medio vende ropa en el mercado de Bellavista.
El primer crédito de 300 soles que recibirà de su Banco comunal Bellavista  II, lo invertirá en la compra ropa (pantalones polares, buzos).
Elsy tiene como sueño tener su tienda de ropa  para crecer como microempresaria.
texts.en:
Ms. Elsy Elizabeth G. A. is 28 years old and lives in the Esperanza district of the province of Trujillo, in the department of La Libertad, Peru.

She did not complete her primary studies, and she has 3 children who depend on her financially.

Elsy sells clothing and provisions for a living. She started out by selling provisions from home. Two-and-a-half years ago, she began selling clothing at the Bellavista Market.

This is her first 300.00 PEN loan from the Bellavista II Microfinance Institute, and she will use it to purchase apparel (sweatpants and track suits).

Elsy dreams of having her own clothing store so that she can grow as a small business owner.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase sweatpants and track suits

loans.name: Sara Rode

texts.es:
La señorita Sara Rode G. López tiene 27 años, vive en el distrito de la Esperanza, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Ella estudió secundaria incompleta, no tiene hijos que depende económicamente de ella, pero sus padres son ancianos y ella trabaja para solventar los gastos de sus ancianos padres.
Sara se dedica a la venta de ajíes molidos, el negocio se inició con su madre hace 25 años, su negocio lo desarrolla en el mercado Bellavista.
Su primer crédito de 300 soles que recibió de su Banco comunal Bellavista  II, lo invirtió en la compra de insumos (ajos, ají panca, culantro) para preparar.
El crédito de 300 soles, lo invertirá en la compra de insumos (ajos, ají panca, culantro) y verduras para implementar su puesto.
Sara tiene como sueño tener su propio puesto de verduras y ajíes molidos  para crecer como microempresaria.
texts.en:
Ms. Sara Rode G. López is 27 years old and lives in the Esperanza district of the province of Trujillo, in the department of La Libertad, Peru.

She did not complete her secondary studies and has no children who depend on her financially, but her parents are elderly, so she has to work to pay for their expenses.

Sara sells chili powder for a living. Her mother started this business, which is located in the Bellavista market, 25 years ago.

She used the first 300.00 PEN loan that she received from Bellavista II Microfinance Institute in purchasing supplies (garlic, Peruvian red peppers, coriander).

This 300.00 PEN loan will be used to purchase garlic, Peruvian red peppers, coriander, and vegetables to restock her stand.

Sara’s dream is to set up her own vegetable and chili powder stand so that she can grow as a small business owner.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase garlic, Peruvian red peppers, coriander, and vegetables

loans.name: Clotilde Martha

texts.es:
La señora Clotilde Martha M. G. tiene 34 años, vive en el distrito de la Esperanza, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Ella estudió secundaria completa, tiene 1 hijo que depende económicamente de ella.
Clotilde se dedica a la venta de pan y pasteles, inicio su negocio sacando el pan a crédito, su negocio lo desarrolla en las calles de su distrito.
Su primer crédito de 300 soles que recibió de su Banco comunal Bellavista  II, lo invertirá en la compra de pan y pasteles para venderlos teniendo así más ganancias.
Clotilde tiene como sueño tener su juguería para crecer como microempresaria.
texts.en:
Clotilde Martha M. G. is 34 years old and she lives in the district of Esperanza, in the province of Trujillo and in the neighborhood of La Libertad in Peru. She finished her high school education and she has one child that she provides for. Clotilde makes a living by selling bread and pastries. She started her business by taking out a loan. Her business has grown on the streets of her neighborhood. Her first loan was for 300 Soles and was through the communal bank Bellavista II. She invested the money in the purchase of bread and pastries to sell and was able to make a profit. Clotilde's dreams is to have her own toy store and to continue to grow as a small business person.

(Translated by Alexis of San Roque High School)

Translated from Spanish by San Roque School, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase bread and pastries to sell and to increase her earnings.

loans.name: Nancy Soledad

texts.es:
La señora Nancy Soledad P. C.  tiene 56 años, vive en el distrito de la Esperanza, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Ella estudió Primaria completa, no tiene  hijos que depende económicamente de ella.
Nancy  se dedica a la venta de productos de pan llevar y tiene un teléfono publico, este negocio se inicio hace 25 años,  su negocio lo desarrolla en su casa.
Su primer crédito de 300 soles que recibió de su Banco comunal Bellavista  II, lo invirtió en la compra de productos como arroz, azúcar, fideos, etc.
El crédito de 300 soles, lo invertirá en la compra productos como arroz, azúcar, fideos para implementar su bodega.
Nancy  tiene como sueño tener su bodega mas implementada y comprarse su congelada para vender helados  para crecer como microempresaria
texts.en:
Nancy Soledad P. C. is 56 years old and she lives in the Esperanza district of the Trujillo region in La Libertad, Peru. She completed primary school, and she has no children that are still dependent on her. Nancy owns a convenience store and she also has a public telephone service. She started her business 25 years ago, a business she runs from her home. With the first loan of 300 soles she received from the Bellavista II community bank (Kiva Field Partner), she made an investment in products such as rice, sugar, pasta, etc. With this loan of 300 soles, she will invest in the purchase of rice, sugar, and pasta, to supply her grocery store. Nancy's dream is to have a better established convenience store and to buy a freezer to be able to sell icecream, to expand her small business.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase products such as rice, sugar, and pasta to supply her convenience store.

loans.name: Elena

texts.es:
La señora Elena R. R.  tiene 26 años, vive en el distrito de la Esperanza, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Ella estudió Secundaria incompleta,  tiene 1 hijo que depende económicamente de ella.
Elena  se dedica a la venta de productos de belleza y a la venta de comida, este negocio se inicio hace un años,  su negocio lo desarrolla en su casa.
Su primer crédito de 300 soles que recibió de su Banco comunal Bellavista  II, lo invirtió en la compra de productos de belleza como cremas, perfumes.
El crédito de 700 soles, lo invertirá en la compra de una cocina, ollas, sillas y mesas para implementar su restaurante y productos de belleza.
Elena  tiene como sueño tener su propio restaurante  para crecer como microempresaria.
texts.en:
Elena R. R. is 26 years old. She lives in the La Esperanza district in the Trujillo area of La Liberta, Peru.

She completed high school and she has a son that is still dependent on her.

She sells beauty products and also runs a catering business. She started this business years ago, running the business from her home.

With the first loan of 300 soles received from the Bellavista II community bank (Kiva Field Partner), she made an investment in the pruchase of beauty products such as skin lotions and perfumes.

With this loan of 700 soles she will make an investment in remodelling her kitchen, including the purchase of pots and pans, tables and chairs with the goal of establishing a restaurant and a place to sell beauty products.

Elena's dream is to have her own restaurant and to grow as a small business owner.


Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase kitchen articles such as pots and pans, tables and chairs to set up a restaurant and a place to sell beauty products.

loans.name: Teresa

texts.es:
La señora Teresa R. D. Leca tiene 62 años, vive en el distrito D. la Esperanza, provincia D. Trujillo, departamento D. La Libertad, Perú.
Ella estudió primaria completa, no tiene hijos que depenD. económicamente D. ella.
Teresa se dedica a la venta D. productos D. pan llevar, el negocio se inicio hace 25 años, su negocio lo desarrolla en su casa.
Su primer crédito D. 300 soles que recibió D. su Banco comunal Bellavista  II, lo invirtió en la compra D. insumos (arroz, azúcar, fideo, galletas).
El crédito D. 300 soles, lo invertirá en la compra D. insumos ((arroz, azúcar, fideo, galletas) y una vitrina.
Teresa tiene como sueño tener su propio un minimarket  para crecer como microempresaria.
texts.en:
Teresa R. D. Leca is 62 years old, and she lives in the La Esperanza district in the Trujillo region, in La Libertad, Peru.

She completed primary school, and she has no children that are still dependent on her.

Teresa runs a conveniece store, a business she started 25 years ago, and she runs it from her home.

Her first loan of 300 soles from the Bellavista II community bank (Kiva Field Partner) was invested in the purchase of items such as rice, sugar, pasta, and cookies.

This loan of 300 soles will be invested in the purchase of rice, sugar, pasta, cookies, and a display case.

Teresa's dream is to have her own minimarket and to grow as a business owner.


Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase items such as rice, sugar, pasta, cookies, and a display case.

loans.name: Carol Lizeth

texts.es:
La señorita Carol Lizeth Velásquez L.  tiene 23 años, vive en el distrito de Florencia de mora, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad, Perú.
Ella estudia Educación Secundaria en la Universidad Nacional de Trujillo, no tiene  hijos que depende económicamente de ella.
Carol  se dedica a la venta de productos de pan llevar este negocio se inicio hace 2 años, asi mismo gracias al préstamo implemento su negocio de venta de comida, sus negocios lo desarrolla en su casa.
Su primer crédito de 300 soles que recibió de su Banco comunal Bellavista  II, lo invirtió en la compra de sillas, mesas para implementar su negocio de venta de comida por las noches.
El crédito de 1000 soles, lo invertirá en la compra productos como arroz, azúcar, fideos para implementar su bodega.
Carol  tiene como sueño tener su bodega mas implementada para crecer como microempresaria.
texts.en:
Carol Lizeth V. L. is 23 years old, and she lives inthe Florencia de Mora district in the region of Trujillo or La Liberta, Peru. She is studying to be high school teacher at the Trujillo National University. She does not have any children that are dependent of her. Carol has been running a convenience store for the past 2 years. Thanks to the loan she received she also set up a catering business, with both businesses run from her home. Her first loan of 300 soles received from the Bellavista II community bank (Kiva Field Partner) was invested in the purchase of chairs and tables to set up to accomodate her food sales in the evenings. This loan of 1000 soles will be invested in the purchase of rice, sugar, and pasta to supply her convenience store. Carol's dream is to have a better established convenience store and to grow as a small business owner.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase rice, sugar, and past to supply her convenience store.

loans.name: Merlyn

texts.en:
Merlyn A. is from the city of Cagayan de Oro. She is 56 years old. Merlyn is married and has 3 school-aged children. Merlyn owns & operates a specialized retail store selling fruits & vegetables. Merlyn has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 2500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Merlyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Merlyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Merlyn is requesting a new loan of PHP 11000 which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Merlyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of the family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the fruit & vegetable retail business.

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
Lorna L. is from the village of Cabunga-an, Calrin, Misamis Occidental. She is 47 years old. Lorna is married and has 5 adult-aged children. To make a living, Lorna operates a business making and selling pork and chicken barbecue. Lorna has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Lorna joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Lorna is requesting a new loan of PHP 5000 to will be used for purchasing meat for making barbecued pork and chicken to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Lorna from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase meat for food business.

loans.name: Jover

texts.en:
Jover T. is from the village of Segatic Daku, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. He is 29 years old. Jover is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Jover owns & operates a business planting & harvesting corn for sale. Jover has been engaged in his business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Jover joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Jover is requesting a loan of PHP 5000. He will use these funds to raise additional crops. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Jover from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business for his family's needs and for his children's allowance and tuition fees. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To raise additional crops.

loans.name: Jason

texts.en:
“You don’t get anywhere standing still. That has always been my motto for life,” says Jason.

Jason has been in the entertainment and music industry for over 15 years, but it was the current popularity of TV singing and dance competitions that inspired him to turn his passion for hip hop music and dance into his own business and an opportunity for local artists. Jason launched Bay Area Battle Tactics, a local competition for singers, dancers, and DJs that can help them gain recognition beyond the San Francisco Bay Area. Jason taught himself graphic design and created his own website to advertise the company, and he recruited friends in the entertainment industry to volunteer and get the project off the ground. 

With a $6,000 loan, Jason can create and distribute flyers and posters, hold auditions, purchase DJ and sound equipment, and hire part-time employees. He hopes that his business will also help reduce inner-city gang violence and unify diverse communities by providing a creative outlet for local youth through music, song, and dance.

Visit http://www.bayareabattletactics.com

Watch of video of Jason: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hZnAmIJraZo&feature=channel_page

loans.use: Promotional activities, marketing campaign, website development, and equipment

loans.name: Hem

texts.en: Hem T., 44, is a local crop farmer who lives in Svay Art Commune of Pursat Province. In addition to her crops, she raises pigs in a pigpen behind her house. She also buys rice in bulk from farmers and puts it into her stock supply for resale, to gain additional income. Her husband, Mr. Bu Veng, 48, earns a living driving a motorcycle taxi and works for the train station. This is her second loan with Kiva and Hem T. will be using this loan to build a store in front of her house where she begin selling groceries. With the remainder of the loan she will purchase additional piglets to raise. She now has six children; two are married and four are in school.

loans.use: To build a store and to buy piglets to raise.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn Cagata is from the town of Opol , Misamis Oriental. She is 56 years old. Evelyn is widowed and has 1 adult child. To make a living, Evelyn owns & operates a specialized retail store where she primarily sells seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Evelyn has been engaged in her business for several years and earns approximately PHP 7000 a month for these activities.

In 2009, Evelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Evelyn is requesting a new loan of PHP 5000. These funds will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Evelyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of the family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products for retail store.

loans.name: Prom

texts.en:
Driving a motorbike taxi is part of 41-year-old Prom C.’s daily routine. He normally gets up in the late morning to pick up passengers and merchandise. He brings his daily income home to meet his hungry family’s needs in the evening. He currently lives with his wife and their two children in a small house in Siem Reap Province. In addition, his wife works selling fish in the market. 
Prom C. has been using his motor for a long time. Recently, he is earning less money than before because his motor is not attractive. Therefore, he has decided to seek a Kiva loan of $1000 in order to buy a new motorbike to replace the existing one. 
He and his wife are pictured.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma O. owns and operates a sari-sari, or general store, selling daily use products such as soap, shampoo, toothpaste, etc. in the local community. She is 44 years old, married and has two school-age children. They are from the village of Tipan, Oroquieta City Misamis Occidental. Emma has been in business for over three years and earns approximately 4500 PHP a month.

In 2008, Emma joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3000 PHP from GDMPC. Emma is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her second loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to supplement the family's income.

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Yamile

texts.en:
In a search for more meaningful work, Yamile had already made a decision to change careers, from advertising to childcare, when she was diagnosed with cancer. Despite this devastating setback, Yamile continued taking childcare courses during her chemotherapy treatment and finally opened her home-based daycare center earlier this year. She believes that the goal of opening her own business gave her strength and helped her overcome her sickness. She is now caring for three toddlers, and her thoughtful teaching curriculum includes music, Spanish, and lots of love. 

With a $5,000 loan, Yamile can put in grass for her outdoor play area, make her backyard safer for children, and convert her garage into a play and nap area to accommodate more children.

loans.use: Improvements for outdoor play area

loans.name: Chita

texts.en:
To make a living, Chita O.'s husband works as a fisherman. Every morning, Chita has to go to the seashore to help her husband weigh the caught fish and sell them immediately to their regular fish buyer. She is 41 years old and has two school-age children. They are from the town of Opol, Misamis Oriental.

In 2009, Chita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve their living conditions. Chita is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase a fishnet and other aids for her husband's fishing activity. This will be her first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve their house, planning to rent it to supplement the family's income.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase a fishnet and other aids for fishing

loans.name: Amanda

texts.en:
Amanda has always worked hard to support her family, while facing a series of personal tragedies—the death of her parents, followed by the loss of her brother to cancer and her stepson to a drunk driver.  Amanda made it through this difficult period, but needed to find a way to support her four children. She invested the money she had to purchase a busy street corner lot and opened a gourmet hot dog stand. Amanda’s only employees are her teenage kids who help her with cooking, cleaning, catering special events, and even bookkeeping. This helps her save money while helping her children develop a strong work ethic.

A $6,500 loan will enable Amanda to purchase an electric panel and an ice machine, which will save her both time and money. Amanda will also invest in fliers and advertisements in local newspapers to boost business.
Visit http://mandyskorner.com/

loans.use: Electric panel, ice machine, and advertising

loans.name: Jeremy

texts.en:
Jeremy is a former ambulance driver and a high-energy entrepreneur.  He runs Emergency BBQ, a mobile catering company that serves up barbecue favorites in a style Jeremy calls California Beer B-Que.  Jeremy is ready to take his business to the next level.
With this loan, Jeremy will expand his business beyond on-the-go catering trucks and open up a retail store in San Carlos. He will be able to cater a greater number of lunch and dinner events from his shop, as well as serve lunch to local workers in San Mateo. He will also be able to create full-time employment for his three seasonal employees.
Visit http://www.emergencybbq.com
Watch a video of Jeremy at: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T6g4dz3r_yo&feature=channel_page

loans.use: to buy furnishings and cooking equipment for his business.

loans.name: Lelia

texts.en:
Lelia D. owns and operates a business making and selling a variety of food products in the local community. She is 44 years old, married and has four adult children. They are from the town of Opol, Misamis Oriental. Lelia has been in business for over three years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Lelia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to support her children's education.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Vika

texts.en:
With her business, Island You a Hand, Vika hires out in-home caretakers, providing companionship for the elderly.  With her diverse and multilingual team of caretakers, which includes Chinese, Russian, Spanish, and other foreign language speakers, she is able to provide a high quality of service.  Vika founded the company in January 2009 with her own savings and a deep commitment to her work. With a background in sales, Vika approaches her business as an aggressive start-up. She has developed relationships with local assisted care facilities, and regularly gives talks at churches in the area to reach out to people directly. Vika sees an opportunity to expand into more technical medical care services, but will need to be certified by the State of California.

This loan will help Vika acquire certification and hire qualified nurses for more technically demanding client placements.

Visit www.islandyouahand.com

loans.use: New certification to expand services

loans.name: Pe

texts.en:
Pe S. currently earns a daily income of $5 from driving a motorbike taxi. He always leaves his house in the early morning to pick up people who are local traders selling merchandise. He mostly provides his service at the busy local marketplace located in and around Phnom Penh City. He is 41 years old, a married man and blessed with three children. All three of them are teenagers attending secondary school. His wife, Peng Eng, 39, is an internal staff member for an organization.

Recently, Pe S.’s motor is not so attractive and his profit is decreasing. Because of this problem, Pe S. would like a loan of $700 in order to purchase a motorbike to replace his existing one. This will help him to attract more customers with income.

loans.use: To purchase a new motorbike

loans.name: Quyên

texts.en:
Quyên Thị P. sells cake in her village every morning. She has a monthly income of about 2.000.000 VND (or $110 US). She wants to earn more money. She needs 4.142.000 VND (or $250 US) to buy wheat flour to make dumplings. Quyên Thị P. was born in 1974. She lives with her husband and two sons in Hội Phụ village, Đông Anh district, Hà Nội city. She is a cluster leader.

No: 010105030048.

loans.use: To buy wheat flour to make dumplings

loans.name: Zonia

texts.en:
Not only does Zonia provide high-quality childcare, but she offers it to some of her community’s most vulnerable residents—families experiencing homelessness.  While some providers think these children and families are too difficult to work with, Zonia embraces the opportunity to work with families going through a difficult time. She loves working with her diverse clientele—the 14 children in her care range from children experiencing homelessness to the children of international embassy staff—and the waiting list for her daycare shows that parents value her services. Zonia has an associate teacher’s permit, and her business has created two full-time jobs.
With this $10,000 loan, Zonia will make needed repairs to her home so that it complies properly with city codes and meets the standards required to hold a childcare provider license.

loans.use: Home Repairs

loans.name: Fatima

texts.en:
Fatima C. makes a living primarily from making and selling specialty food products in the local fish port where many vendors are her frequent customers. She is 49 years old, married and has two adult children. She is from the town of Opol, Misamis Oriental. Fatima has been in business for over one year and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Fatima joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Fatima is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to support her children's education.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaC. out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Obdulia

texts.en:
Obdulia helped support her family with an office job in electronics while her husband worked as a car mechanic.  When Obdulia was laid off, she saw an opportunity to combine her office experience with her husband’s automotive skills.  Using their savings, they opened Family Auto Repair together in 2007.  But their savings were not enough to cover essential tools and advertising, and Obdulia’s application for a bank line of credit was denied, leaving them unable to make key investments in their business.
A $10,000 loan enables Obdulia to build her business because she will be able to pay for the tools they need and advertise Family Auto Repair’s services to the community.

loans.use: Tools, equipment, and advertising

loans.name: Choeun

texts.en:
S., 27, earns a living by selling grocery inventory from her house--selling items such as cooked food and sweets for kids. She has had experience in this business for a long time. S. is married and currently takes care of three children, all of whom are single and also attend school, whilst her husband is an office staff member for a transportation company. They live in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia.

S. works hard every day and is very responsible for her family. Recently, she has sold all the groceries from her store. Because grocery selling is S.'s main source of income to support her family, she would like a loan to purchase a range of grocery items to sell. The remaining amount will be used to repair a broken motorbike.

loans.use: To purchase a range of groceries to sell and to repair a broken motorbike

loans.name: Menchie

texts.en:
Menchie A. is from the town of Opol in Misamis Oriental, Philippines. She is 43 years old. Menchie is married and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Menchie sells seafood, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Menchie has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Menchie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Menchie is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP that she will use to expand her business. This loan will Menchie's first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to educate her children and provide for the needs of her family.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Hoa

texts.en: Hoa Thị Nguyễn was born in 1980. She lives with her parents-in-law, her husband, and their two children. She has a confectionery. She also makes bamboo brooms. She has a monthly income of about 2.500.000 VND. She wants to expand the range of goods that she sells, so she needs 2.668.000 VND (~ $175 USD) to buy items, such as chairs, tables, and bowls, to sell.

loans.use: To buy chairs, tables, and bowls to sell.

loans.name: Carl

texts.en:
“You have to be willing to sacrifice a lot, to work Saturdays and Sundays, and just be honest and fair,” says Carl.

Carl worked for 20 years in the trucking industry and washed windows on the side for extra money, before deciding to start his own window washing business. Carl manages the business and washes windows–often waking at 3:00 in the morning for early jobs–while his wife helps out with bookkeeping. Carl’s business capacity has doubled in the last few years and could keep growing, but he needs to invest in advertising and hire a full-time employee to meet the high demand. 

A $5,000 loan would help Carl advertise his business online and in real estate brochures, as well as prepare the business to hire a full-time employee. 

Visit http://www.mobilewashingservice.com/

loans.use: Advertising and hiring new employee

loans.name: Amato

texts.en:
Amato, a widowed mother of two, has always loved children and believes her mission in life is to help them. For over ten years, she worked with disadvantaged children at various nonprofits before being laid off in 2003.  She began fostering children and decided to take this effort one step further by opening a daycare center in her home in California. Amato hopes that the individual care and attention each child receives at Village d’Afrique will teach them great values and give them the opportunity to flourish in life. She’d like to provide this opportunity to more children, but needs funds to fully convert her home into a daycare center with a higher capacity.
With a $6,000 loan from Opportunity Fund, Amato will be able to carpet the living room nap area, convert her garage into a play room, and buy art and educational supplies. Currently, Amato has three children in her bilingual French and English daycare program, but she hopes that the loan will expand her capacity to care for more children.

loans.use: Carpet nap area, convert garage to play room, and buy educational and art supplies

loans.name: Nhoek

texts.en:
Mrs. K., age 33, has been married for many years. She has been a silk weaver for 19 years, a skill she learned from her grandmother. She has three children who attend school. All of them assist her with weaving silk when they are free from their studies.

Mrs. K. sells her finished products to a middleman who resells them at the market in Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. The villagers also hire Mrs. K. to spin silk, and she earns extra income from these jobs. In addition, her husband owns a car and uses it to pick up passers-by for income.

Mrs. K. hopes to earn more profits, so she is requesting a loan to buy mango in bulk from farmers and then sell the mango retail in the market for a profit. She will also use 40% of loan to repair a broken car.

loans.use: To buy mango in bulk from farmers

loans.name: Nhung's Group

texts.en:
Nhung Hồng Chử was born in 1987. Her husband is a laborer and they have a child. They have a monthly income of about 3.000.000 VND (~ $180 USD).

Every day, she sells fruit in the market. Nhung Hồng Chử is a member of a two-member borrower group. She wants to borrow 1.972,000 VND (~ $118 USD) to buy more fruit to sell.

The other borrower in her group, Lân Thị Đỗ, was born in 1950. She wants to borrow 2.204.000 VND (~ $132 USD) to buy bamboo to make brooms.

loans.use: To buy more fruit to sell

loans.name: Genayda

texts.en:
Genayda A. is from the town of Opol in Misamis Oriental, Philippines. She is 44 years old. Genayda is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Genayda owns and operates a specialized retail store in which she sells a variety of products, such as spices, along the fishport. Genayda has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month from her business.

In 2009, Genayda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Genayda is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP that she will use to expand her business. This loan will be Genayda's first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to educate her children and support her family.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Huong

texts.en: Hương Thị Đỗ was born in 1975.  She lives with her father in-law, husband and two children. She makes and sells brooms. Her monthly income is about 2.000.000 VND. She wants to borrow 2.204.000 VND to buy bamboo to make brooms.

loans.use: Buy bamboo to make brooms.

loans.name: Chi

texts.en: Chi T. V. was born in 1946. There are five member in her family. She mainly works in the fields of agricultural, animal and vegetable.  Chi also makes paper pockets at home.  Her husband is a construction worker.  The average family income is about 2,500,000 Vietnamese Dong.  She wants to borrow 4.548.000 VND to buy paper and food for domestic animals.

loans.use: Buy paper and food for domestic animal.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Ban's Group

texts.en: This loan involves three borrowers who live in Phnom Penh. The group's leader, Ban T., makes a living raising pigs in a stall behind her house. She can raise pigs and sells to buyers every three month. She has three children who are single and school-age. To help meet the family's foods needs, her husband buys cows to raise and sell to a farmer to gain income. To make additional income, T. is applying for a loan to purchase pigs and oxen to raise for sale. Two other borrowers have joined this loan:  V. will be using a loan to buy fishing tools for her husband to begin fishing.  C. requests a loan to purchase small fish to feed in her pond behind her house.

loans.use: Purchase pigs and oxen to raise for sale

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en:
Wilma P. is from the town of Opol in Misamis Oriental, Philippines. She is 43 years old. Wilma is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Wilma buys and sells fish. Wilma has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Wilma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Wilma is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which she will use to purchase an additional fishing net. This will be Wilma's first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to educate her children and support her family.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase an additional fishing net

loans.name: Lien's Group

texts.en:
Liên Thị Bích Hoàng was born in 1965. ( no: 010110040037 ). Her family has a bazaar at home. She works in a livestock farm and, in addition, she breed pigs and poultry at home. She lives with her husband, who is a soldier, and their two children. She has a monthly income of about 4.500.000 VND. She wants to borrow 2.436.000 VND (~ $145 USD) to buy goods to sell.

There are four other borrowers in her loan group.

  • Hiệp Thị Đồng was born in 1965. (no: 010110040038). She is raising 200 chickens, 150 wild geese. She wants to borrow 2.436.000 VND (~ $145 USD) to buy poultry feed.
  • Hằng Thị Nguyễn was born in 1969.(no: 010110040040). She has a hairdresser’s shop. She wants to borow 2.436.000 VND(~ $145 USD) to expand her shop.
  • Oanh K. Thị Nguyễn was born in 1978. (no: 010110040039). She sells vegetables in the market. She wants to borrow 2.436.000 VND (~ $145 USD) to buy more vegetables to sell.
  • Cầm Thị Ngô was born in 1969. (no: 010110040041 ). She is a tailor. She wants to borrow 2.436.000 VND (~ $145 USD) to buy cloth to make clothes.

loans.use: To buy goods to sell

loans.name: Rehana Ashraf Masih Group

texts.en:
Rehana baji, the wife of A. M., has lived in the mid-sized city of Riwind, Pakistan for the past 10 years. Her husband is a vegetable seller by profession. He buys vegetables wholesale and sells them to vegetable shops to earn income. He has been engaged in this business for the past three years.

Rehana baji is a very hardworking woman. She embroiders dresses on order to share the financial burden of her husband. She is applying for a loan to buy seasonal vegetables to increase her husband's profits.

Rehana baji is the leader of a group of five women from her locality. Sugran baji wants a loan to buy seasonal vegetables to sell. Rani baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for loading. Rani baji wants a loan to buy beams for her shuttering business. Irshad baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo for her milk-selling business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy seasonal vegetables to sell

loans.name: Nasreen Arshad Masih Group

texts.en:
Nasreen baji, the wife of A. M., has lived in the mid-size city of Riwind, Pakistan for the past 10 years. She is not educated, because her parents couldn’t afford her educational expenses. Her husband drives a donkey cart that transports fruits and vegetables from one place to another. He has been in this business for the past 2 years. Nasreen baji is applying for a loan to buy a new donkey cart for her husband, because his old cart has become rough and rotted with wear.

Nasreen baji is the leader of a group of five women from her locality. Parveen baji, Shakeela baji, and Saima baji each want a loan to buy donkey carts for loading. Hanifan baji wants a loan to buy beads, colored thread and cloth for her decorative embroidery business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Note: "Baji," which means "older sister," is a term of respect for women in Pakistan.

loans.use: To buy a new donkey cart

loans.name: Thuy's Group

texts.en:
Thủy Bích Lý was born in 1962 and has two children. She sells fruit in the market, and she breeds pigs and poultry. She has a monthL. income of about 3.000.000 VND. She wants to borrow 5.014.000 VND ($285 USD) to buy more fruit to sell and to buy food for her pigs. 

Thủy Bích Lý is a group leader. There are five other Fund participants in her group: 

Hoan Thị Nguyễn was born in 1966. She wants to borrow 5.014.000 VND ($285 USD) to buy food for pigs and poultry.

Chiến Thị Ngô was born in 1978. She wants to borrow 5.014.000 VND ($285 USD) to breed pigs and poultry.

Doanh Thị Lưu was born in 1962. She wants to borrow 5.014.000 VND ($285 USD) to breed chickens.
 
Xuân Thị Trịnh was born in 1962. She wants to borrow 5.014.000 VND ($285 USD) to raise pigs.

Duyên Thị Tạ was born in 1959. She wants to borrow 5.014.000 VND ($285 USD) to breed pigs and poultry.

loans.use: to buy more fruit to sell and buy food for pigs

loans.name: Anayat Abdul Masih Group

texts.en:
Anayat baji is a wife of A. M.. They have lived in Riwind, Pakistan for 15 years. Her husband sells medicine. He buys medicines wholesale and sells to different medical shops. Anayat baji is a very sensitive and caring lady. She performs her duties as a wife and as a woman efficiently. She is applying for a loan to expand her husband’s medicine-selling business. 

She is the group leader of two other women from her locality. Salma baji wants a loan to buy mobile phones to sell. Nazia baji wants a loan to buy timbers to sell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy medicines to sell

loans.name: The's Group

texts.en:
Thể Thị Bích Chử was born in 1968. She is a teacher. She lives with her husband and two children. Her husband is a worker. They have a monthly income of about 3.000.000 VND. She breeds pigs and poultry, and she wants to borrow 5.014.000 VND ($285 USD) to buy food for them. 

There are four other Fund participants in her group: 
 
Chiến Thị Nguyễn was born in 1950. She wants to borrow 4.142.000 VND ($235 USD) to breed pigs and poultry.

Nguyên Thị Nguyễn  was born in 1958. She wants to borrow 5.014.000 VND ($285 USD) to buy meat to resell.

Hà Thị P. was born in 1961. She is a teacher. She wants to borrow 5.014.000 VND (285 USD) to raise pigs.

Thanh Thị Lệ Ngô was born in 1973. She is a teacher. She wants to have a bigger income. She wants to borrow 5.014.000 VND ($285 USD) to raise pigs.

loans.use: To buy food for domestic animal

loans.name: Khursheed Gulzar Group

texts.en:
Khursheed baji is a wife of Mr. G. who has lived in Riwind, Pakistan for the past 10 years. She is the group leader of this loan group. All of the members respect her a lot because of her good nature and caring behavior. Her husband runs a vehicle oil selling business. He sells oil to workshops. She is applying for a loan to increase the profit of her husband’s vehicle oil selling business. 

The other members of the group are:

Kosar baji, who wants a loan to buy material (beads, colored thread, and clothes) for her embroidery business. 

Parveen baji, who wants a loan to buy beams for her shuttering business. 

Rani baji, who wants a loan to buy seasonal vegetables to sell. 

Chaman baji, who wants a loan to buy clothes to sell. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy vehicles oil to sell

loans.name: Hoa's Group

texts.en:
Hoa Thị Đậu was born in 1959. There are four people in her family: her husband, two sons, and herself.  They have a bazaar at home. In addition, she breeds pigs and poultry. They have a monthly income of about 3.500.000 VND. She wants to borrow 6.322.000 VND ($350 USD) to buy goods to sell in their bazaar.

She has an attitude of service and loves being able to help women with their clothing needs.

Munojot has requested a loan of $1100 to purchase new inventory of women's summer clothing. This loan will help her to continue developing her business and provide a good income for her family.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

The children Silvia cares for, and some of their parents, call her “abuela,” Spanish for grandma, which captures the feeling of extended family that keeps families coming to her.  

With a $10,000 loan, Silvia can build an outdoor storage shed, so that she can stop paying $200 a month to rent one.  This investment will also enable Silvia to upgrade outdoor areas to provide adequate play space for children.

The business gives Rodney a chance to do what he loves for a living, while raising awareness about Hawaiian culture.

A $2,000 loan helps Rodney grow his business by establishing a commercial location and furnishing it with tables, chairs, filing cabinets, a computer and other teaching materials.
